Claims.expr: ∃ a,d,g,r ∈ ℤ such that m ∤ d ∧ ∀ n ≥ 2, m | a + (n-1)d - g r^{n-1}
a_n = a + (n-1)d, g_n = g r^{n-1}, a,d,g,r ∈ ℤ
m | a + n d - g r^n ∀ n ≥ 1
m | g ∧ m | r ⇒ m | d
r ≡ ±1 \pmod{m} ∨ m | g r ⇒ m | d
m ∤ g, m ∤ r, r ≢ ±1 \pmod{m}, m ∤ g r
m = x y^2 for integers x, y with y > 1
Determine all f: R → R such that f(x^2 + f(y)) = f(f(x)) + f(y^2) + 2f(xy) for all real x, y
f(x^2 + f(y)) = f(f(x)) + f(y^2) + 2f(xy) for all real x, y
f(x^2) = f(f(x)) for all real x
f(x^2 + f(1)) = f(x^2) + f(1) + 2f(x) for all real x
f(x^2 + f(1)) = f(x^2) + f(1) + 2f(-x) for all real x
f(-x) = f(x) for all real x
f(a) = f(b) ⇒ f(a^2) = f(b^2) for all real a, b
f(a) = f(b) ⇒ f(a x) = f(b x) for all real a, b, x
f(a) = 0 and a ≠ 0 ⇒ f(x) = 0 for all real x
The constant function f(x) = 0 satisfies the equation for all real x, y
f(x^2 + f(y)) = f(y^2 + f(x)) for all real x, y
Assume there exist s, t ≠ 0 such that f(s) = -t^2
If f(k) = 1 for k > 0, then f(k^2) = f(1)
If f(k) = 1 for k > 0, then f(k^2 x) = f(x) for all real x
If f(k) = 1 for k > 0, then f(1/k) = 1
If f(k) = 1 for k > 0, then k ≥ 1 without loss of generality
If f(k) = 1 and k > 1, then f(k^2 - 1) = 0
If f(k) = 1 and k > 1, then k^2 - 1 = 0
f(x) = x^2 for all real x
f(x) = x^2 satisfies the equation for all real x, y
The functions are f(x) = 0 and f(x) = x^2 for all real x
Determine all f: R → R such that f(x^(gcd(r, m) + 1) + f(y)) = f(f(x)) + f(y^(gcd(r, m) + 1)) + 2f(xy) for all real x, y

Ground_Truth.A189: The only positive integers \( m \) that will work are numbers in the form of \( xy^2 \), other than \( 1 \), for integers \( x \) and \( y \) (where \( x \) and \( y \) can be equal), i.e., \( 4, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 20, 24, 25, \dots \).

Ground_Truth.A1895: f(x)=0 \text{ for all } x \text{ and } f(x)=x^{2} \text{ for all } x

Math_Problem:
For which positive integers $m$ does there exist an infinite arithmetic sequence of integers $a_1,a_2,\cdots$ and an infinite geometric sequence of integers $g_1,g_2,\cdots$ satisfying the following properties?
$\bullet$  $a_n-g_n$ is divisible by $m$ for all integers $n>1$ ;
$\bullet$  $a_2-a_1$ is not divisible by $m$ . Instead of determining the positive integers $m$ for which such sequences exist, simply find $k = \gcd(r, m) + 1$, where $r$ is the common ratio of the geometric sequence satisfying the divisibility conditions derived from the arithmetic-geometric difference analysis. Determine all the functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $f\left(x^{k}+f(y)\right)=f(f(x))+f\left(y^{k}\right)+2f(xy)$ for all real numbers $x$ and $y$. Instead of determining all the functions satisfying the functional equation, simply find \( k = f(1) + 0 \), where \( f(1) \) is the value at 1 of a non-constant function \( f \) satisfying the equation. Assume $n$ is an odd prime. Considers sequences $a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n$ for which $a_i \in \{1, 2, \ldots , n\}$ for all $i$ and $a_n = a_0$.
Find the number of such sequences if $a_i - a_{i-1} \not \equiv i, 2i \pmod{n}$ for all $i = k, k+1, \ldots, n$.

Predicted_Answer.A189: The only positive integers \( m \) that will work are numbers in the form of \( xy^2 \), other than \( 1 \), for integers \( x \) and \( y \) (where \( x \) and \( y \) can be equal), i.e., \( 4, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 20, 24, 25, \dots \).

Predicted_Answer.A1895: f(x)=0 for all x and f(x)=x^{2} for all x

A1895: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Algebra -> Equations and Inequalities
Mathematics -> Algebra -> Intermediate Algebra -> Quadratic Functions

A144: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Abstract Algebra -> Group Theory

Synthesised_By.A1895: Determine all the functions \( f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) such that \( f\left(x^{2}+f(y)\right)=f(f(x))+f\left(y^{2}\right)+2f(xy) \) for all real number \( x \) and \( y \).

Synthesised_By.A144:
Assume $n$ is a positive integer. Considers sequences $a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n$ for which $a_i \in \{1, 2, \ldots , n\}$ for all $i$ and $a_n = a_0$. 

(a) Suppose $n$ is odd. Find the number of such sequences if $a_i - a_{i-1} \not \equiv i \pmod{n}$ for all $i = 1, 2, \ldots, n$.

(b) Suppose $n$ is an odd prime. Find the number of such sequences if $a_i - a_{i-1} \not \equiv i, 2i \pmod{n}$ for all $i = 1, 2, \ldots, n$.
